Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Survival and performance costs of phenotypic responses to predation risk
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study investigates whether young songbirds that grow faster and leave the nest earlier because of a higher risk of nest predation have lower survival rates after leaving the nest. Predation can be a major source of mortality in wild animal populations. When the risk of predation is variable, prey species are expected to show flexible developmental responses that reduce their risk of being killed by predators. For example, young birds may grow faster and leave the nest earlier when nest predation risk is high. However, flexible developmental responses at early life stages may be physiologically costly and increase mortality at later life stages. By simulating increased predation, the researchers will experimentally determine the effects of variable nest predation on nestling growth rate and timing of fledging for Dark-eyed Juncos. Each bird will be tagged with a radio transmitter to determine their fates after leaving the nest. The study will also address whether activity levels and behaviors of fledglings reduce mortality risks and compensate for physiological costs. Results will provide critical insights on the key factors that control the growth and decline of wild animal populations, and lead to more effective management of these populations. In addition, the project will involve mentoring of both undergraduate and graduate students, and will develop educational materials for high school students. Educational videos for school age children will also be created for a local science education center.

This project tests the hypothesis that faster growth of Dark-eyed Juncos in response to nest predation risk compromises mobility and causes increased mortality risk at older life history stages. Researchers will use speakers to broadcast sounds of typical nest predators to increase the perception of nest predation risk by parents and offspring to examine its consequences for mortality after fledging. Preliminary data show that young nestlings in 'high risk' nests leave the nest with shorter wings and are less adept at flying, but it is unclear if these same individuals are predated more often after leaving. Just before the nestlings leave the nest the researchers will attach radio transmitters to aid in tracking. Data will be collected on how often and how far the young birds move around each day after they leave the nest; whether they hide more often in denser vegetation where predators, like hawks, have greater difficulty getting to them; and whether they actually are more likely to die. Results will advance our understanding of carryover effects from growth plasticity on offspring mortality during later life stages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Predation is an important source of mortality in wild populations in a wide variety of animals from plankton to mammals. Prey can often recognize when the level of predation risk in the environment is high and flexibly develop traits that reduce their chances of being killed and eaten by predators. Such flexible responses in young animals are especially important because young tend to be more vulnerable to predation and survival until reproductive ages is essential for population growth. However, developing traits that help reduce predation early in life may create costs if these traits are no longer appropriate during later life stages. For example, in songbirds, flexible behavioral and growth responses to predation risk by young that are still in the nest can result in young that leave the nest with shorter wings. Short wings can impair their ability to fly well and, potentially, increase mortality from predation after leaving the nest. In nature, young with short wings might change their behavior by choosing safer habitat to compensate for poor flight ability and thereby avoid higher mortality after leaving the nest. However, previous research has not considered this sort of compensatory behavior. 

Examining how important such compensatory mechanisms are for survival of young animals in the wild is critical for making predictions about how flexible responses to predation risk will affect survival, recruitment of young into the breeding population and, ultimately, population growth. Being able to make sound predictions about how predation pressure will impact populations will help managers make smarter and more efficient use of their limited funds. Additionally, studying how plastic responses to predation risk influence survival later in life can help us understand what constrains the evolution of developmental flexibility. 

We used a species of songbird to examine how flexible responses by young to increased predation risk while in the nest influences flight performance, behavior and survival after leaving the nest. We found that young from high predation risk nests grew wings slower resulting in shorter wings, showed poor flight performance, and experienced higher mortality after leaving the nest. Young could compensate for slower wing growth by staying in the nest longer, but we did not find evidence to support the idea they were compensating for having short wings by altering their habitat use. Ultimately, we found that flexible responses to predation risk in early life stages create survival costs in later life stages. 

 

Broader Impacts:

This project created training opportunities for both graduate students and other aspiring biologists just finished with their undergraduate studies. Two field technicians received training on numerous field ornithological techniques including nest searching, measuring adults and young, and tracking fledgling using radio telemetry. Training the technicians in the field also created a mentoring opportunity for the graduate student to discuss how to conduct strong inference science and provide guidance on career paths in the biological sciences. Additionally, starting in October 2018, results and videos from the proposed study will be used to create an educational activity for children at a local science education center in Missoula, MT. Birds are charismatic organisms that are easily relatable to children of all ages and the films and morphological measurements produced for the proposed study are amenable to learning about development, morphology, and function. Furthermore, variation in wing size, mobility, and predator-caused mortality provide an easily understandable example for discussing how natural selection works with older students. This project also has clear implications for conservation. Specifically, in songbirds, both the nestling and fledgling stages are known to be periods of high mortality with strong effects on population dynamics. However, studies examining mortality factors during the fledgling stage are rare. Our findings highlight how nest predation risk can influence fledgling mortality and provide a background for management interventions meant to improve recruitment in wild populations.
